Experiences.Title: PhD Student in Computer Science (Present)
Experiences.Description: I am interested in studying how machine learning is changing the way we design software-systems and applications, including the way we think about fundamental systems abstractions and tradeoffs. I am part of Hazy Lab and advised by Prof. Chris RÃ©.

Experiences.Title: Research Scientist (Summer 2021)
Experiences.Description: I led a project on personalizing retrieval-based systems with Jacob Kahn, Patrick Lewis, and Angela Fan. We wrote up a paper on this work called: Reasoning over Public and Private Data in Retrieval-Based Systems.

Experiences.Title: Global Technology Investment Banking (Summer 2018)
Experiences.Company: Morgan Stanley Menlo Park, Summer Analyst
Experiences.Description: As a summer analyst with Morgan Stanley's Tech Banking group in Menlo Park, CA, the closed deals I worked on include the sale of AMS to IPG ($2.3 Bn), the sale of Cylance to Blackberry ($1.4 Bn), and the August 2nd Sonos IPO on Nasdaq (which I was lucky enough to attend in person!).

Experiences.Title: Researcher in the NetDB Lab (Fall '17 - Winter '19)
Experiences.Description: My research focused on developing systems to optimize the communication overhead of tasks distributed across datacenter clusters, based on the physical topology of the datacenter and the workload properties.

Experiences.Title: Software Engineering (Summer 2017)
Experiences.Description: I worked on the open source Closure-Compiler, which is used by flagship Google teams (e.g., Gmail, Drive, Maps) to reduce the size of the shipped JavaScript code. The most significant update to the JavaScript programing language is ES6 (2015).  I worked on updating compiler from ES3 to ES6, to be able to compile ES6 features and output ES6 code. My code from this internship is available here: https://github.com/google/closure-compiler.

Experiences.Title: Researcher in the GRASP Lab (Spring '16 - Fall '16)
Experiences.Description: We developed a nanofabricated device to control distributed systems of micro-bio robots, which has eventual applications in directed drug delivery and microsurgery. The device induces magnetic fields to control the micro-robots, and I formalized the theory and built a computer simulation to model the device's physics.

Experiences.Title: Physics Research
Experiences.Description: This lab focuses on the physics of explosives used by the United States Navy. The explosive composites are often subjected to extreme temperatures, shocks, and pressures in the field, which can lead to unintended detonations. I worked on the development of a molecular sensor that is used to study the volatile material properties.

Experiences.Title: Looma Intern
Experiences.Description: Many schools in resource-limited developing nations lack the basic necessities for enhanced education: infrastructure, reliable electricity, Internet access, and quality educational content. I worked on project management and hardware engineering for Looma, a low-cost audiovisual device that includes interactive whiteboard capability, Internet connectivity, access to online and offline educational content, and local storage capability.

Teaching.Title: Lead TA in designing the MCIT 595 Computer Systems Coursera course (Spring '19)
Teaching.Company: University of Pennsylvania, Department of Computer Science
Teaching.Description: I led a team of TA's in designing MCIT 595 Computer Systems Coursera course, which is part of Penn's online masters degree program. This involved creating lecture scripts, course quizzes and exams, and lecture slides. I also created a tutorial video on VMs which is part of the online Coursera content.

Teaching.Title: TA for CIS 380 Operating Systems (Fall '18)
Teaching.Company: University of Pennsylvania, Department of Computer Science
Teaching.Description: Amongst other TA duties (e.g., office hours, grading), I mentored student teams in the month-long project to design and build PennOS, an OS with kernel/scheduler and file-system subsystems.

Teaching.Title: TA for CIS 160 Discrete Math (Fall '17, Spring '18)
Teaching.Company: University of Pennsylvania, Department of Computer Science
Teaching.Description: Amongst other TA duties (e.g., office hours, grading), I taught an hour-long recitation section of 15 students each week, to supplement the course lectures. The course content includes set theory, logic and proof techniques, probability, combinatorics, and graph theory.
